text: I love dulce de leche in every possible
way
in Argentina and much of Latin America
they sandwich it between two buttery
shortbread cookies and they're called
alfajores there are a lot of ways to
make dulce de leche the easiest is to
take a can of sweetened condensed milk
and then boil it in a big pot of water
for a couple of hours until the milk
sugars caramelize and then the whole
thing just becomes this rich buttery Jam
put the can on its side because if you
put it straight up and down it's gonna
go like this it's gonna clatter and make
a terrible racket in your kitchen the
one thing about making dulce de leche is
the can could explode it I know it
sounds scary but just don't let the
water boil away and you're fine you see
the boiling water keeps the temperature
constant at 212 degrees and once the
water goes away the can can get hotter
and hotter and hotter and that is when
it explodes you feel better so the
fastest way to get your dulce de leche
into your sandwich cookie is to use a
plastic bag and we'll show you you open
the can you take a minute and just you
know check for quality control you swoon
this just goes right into the bag come
on alfajores gained popularity in Latin
America after the corn starch company
printed the recipe on the back of the
box because the shortbread cookies use a
high percentage of corn starch in the
dough and it gives them a particularly
crumbly very delicate texture one great
thing about alfajores is that they
change over time
so the first day you make them the
cookies are very crisp and then as the
days go by the cookies get a little bit
softer a little bit more like cake and
they're great both ways and by the way
if you don't like coconut just leave it
out you don't need to do this of course
if you like you can just dispense with
the whole cookie thing and just make the
dulce de leche and then you can eat it
by itself with a spoon
I just love dil se de leche
Oh
